utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: A 41-year-old U.K. man ended up with a life-threatening infection that required open-heart surgery, all thanks to a peace of movie popcorn lodged in his tooth. How did it happen and how can happen to you. Dr. Marc Siegel is Fox News medical correspondent and he joins us now.

utterances.speaker: DR. MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hi, Mark.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Dr. Siegel, how did this trip to the movies end up with open heart surgery.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: First of all, it is a lesson to everyone out there because we're all putting our hands in our mouth. So this man got a piece of popcorn stuck in the back tooth. And he was putting everything in there trying to get it out -- wire toothpicks, tops of pens -- and finally even a metal nail.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: And the metal nail is famous for having a lot of bacteria on it and the gums are a bacterial highway to the heart, similar to as a drug abuser, putting bacteria into the veins. That's why we're seeing so many heart valve infections. We have 15,000 in the United States every year, so he went to see Mark, his primary care doctor in Cornwall, England, who saw that he had fevers and sweats and a heart murmur and sent him home. Now, here in the United States, I would do an echo -- and echocardiogram to examine the valves of the heart. I'm shocked that he was sent home, but it may in fact be an indictment of the National Health Service that that actually happened.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Well, we always like indicting the National Health Service just for Elizabeth Warren's sake, but just be clear on this. When President Garfield got shot, it is said that it wasn't the bullet that killed him, but everyone poking around inside and trying to find the bullet. And something similar happened here. It's not the popcorn, it's all the stuff he put in his mouth poking around to try and get at the popcorn, which is what everyone does.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: And that's the moral of the story. The gums guns are loaded with blood vessels with veins and if you make them bleed, and you get an abscess in those gums, you better see your dentist right away, because that abscess can feed the bloodstream, which then feeds the heart. You don't even have to have -- now what is the valve? It's the chambers of the heart opening and closing. They're very susceptible to bacteria in the bloodstream, so I would warn everybody out there not to poke around with foreign objects like we all do. This could happen to you, and then it ends up with a $50,000.00 hospitalization and surgery.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: But why even do you see in some restaurants toothpicks?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Well, toothpicks are okay provided that they're clean, provided that to use them for a specific device, but medically floss is much safer, brushing your teeth is much safer.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Okay, thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: I would say one more thing. I would advise everyone out there, watch Netflix or Hulu or Fox. Don't go to movie theaters because popcorn is rampant there.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Yeah, popcorn.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.sentences: Watch out for popcorn.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.sentences: Thank you Dr. Siegel. Popcorn. It's America's silent killer. It's coming for you. Dr. Siegel, thanks for that. That's about it for us tonight. Tune in each night at eight to the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, groupthink and even killer popcorn. So, I, sir, I have a feeling you know what you're doing. I'm going to harness love for political purposes. I will meet you on that field and sir, love will win.

We've already shot past 100,000 selfies.

And she said, well, I was doing it for my family.  You know, I think Mayor Bloomberg, or Tom Steyer would say they were doing it for their families, too.  But you know, Mark, how about how about Buttigieg? One of the other telltale signs that he is in the C.I.A., apparently -- did you just read this. He has blue eyes.

utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.utterance: Blue eyes.

utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.utterance: And that made me think, wait a second. Elizabeth Warren has blue eyes, too. She's not a C.I.A. asset. She's a Cherokee?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.utterance: You know.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: They might not really, given what we know about Elizabeth Warren that nothing is what it appears to be. She might actually just have brown eyes and she's had them tinted, Howie. You never know.  I want to ask you about Marianne Williamson because she is a mistress of the spirit world, so she might well at this stage be sticking pins in the other candidate's voodoo dolls.  Oh, yeah, there she is. I think she is -- who is she sticking a pin in? Elizabeth Warren. I can sympathize with her on that.

utterances.speaker: CARR

You know, I when I think of Elizabeth Warren, you know, don't you get the Carnac, the magnificent five there, you know, you keep waiting for her.  I don't know what the problem with her crystal ball, though, because I knew she was going nowhere. I don't know about you.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.utterance: Now that I think about it, Mark, have you ever seen Alfred E. Neuman and Mayor Pete in the same room?

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: No, I haven't. But we'll get working on that, Howie. It would be a fascinating sight. Thank you for that. The great Howie Carr, who is a close student of all Elizabeth Warren's activities. Thank you, Howie.

utterances.speaker: CARR
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Mark.

utterances.utterance: Nothing's changed. Yes. And AOC and Joe Biden have to be in the same party and they need to come together and talk about things that they have in common.

utterances.speaker: STEYN

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.utterance: No, I really don't think that this is a problem. You know, I think that it's really important that everybody sticks to their ideological positions. But at the same time, I think that there are things that we all agree upon. We all agree that there is an existential threat from climate change. For example, we all agree that the middle class needs to have their share, you know, in this country. utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Well, let's just say that climate change business because AOC said the world was going to end in 12 years, so she said that last year, so I think we're 11 years now -- 2031, the world is going to end. She seems pretty sincere about that. When you look at the guys like Joe Biden that just seems -- they just seem to be going along, and isn't that why the so-called moderate side has no energy because in fact, they are -- there is no authenticity in that side of it.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.utterance: Well, listen, I will tell you this, I think that radical important change is never brought about by moderates. There are certain people that are willing to have the conversation about things like climate change and racial and ethnic justice and those kinds of things that you know, other side -- the other side doesn't want to have the conversation.  So it's important to pull those people in and let them know that you know, being moderate doesn't create change.

utterances.utterance: Okay, Jason, you're a big tent man and Elizabeth Warren knows all about that. Thank you. Thank you for that, Jason.  Nancy Pelosi is finally ready. JENNA ELLIS, SENIOR LEGAL ADVISER, TRUMP 2020 CAMPAIGN: Well, I think it means that she was not able to bully the Senate into doing her bidding and that's a great thing for the Constitution and for our separation of powers.  And President Trump is absolutely right that her tactics are just political stunts. utterances.utterance: Yes, unfortunately, the Democrats have been trying all of these political stunts simply to oust President Trump since he first took office. We, the people, voted for President Trump. He is in office and even though the Democrats don't like that, you don't wield and weaponize the power of impeachment that's given to the House zero, zero, zero, zero, zero will never ever equal an impeachable offense. utterances.speaker: ELLIS
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, you know, when you're on the side of the truth, and you're on the side of the rule of law in the Constitution, I think it's a great day for America when that wins out over these political stunts. And so nothing that the Democrats have done has ultimately been successful. They've played every single card in their hand. utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: She gave the impression that she liked to impeach him for Iran. I mean, they could seriously be doing the Impeachment of the Month Club.

utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thank you for that, Jenna. That's the definitive pronouncement, I think.

utterances.speaker: ELLIS

utterances.speaker: STEYN

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: A 41-year-old U.K. man ended up with a life-threatening infection that required open-heart surgery, all thanks to a peace of movie popcorn lodged in his tooth. How did it happen and how can happen to you. Dr. Marc Siegel is Fox News medical correspondent and he joins us now.

utterances.speaker: DR. MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hi, Mark.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Dr. Siegel, how did this trip to the movies end up with open heart surgery.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: First of all, it is a lesson to everyone out there because we're all putting our hands in our mouth. So this man got a piece of popcorn stuck in the back tooth. And he was putting everything in there trying to get it out -- wire toothpicks, tops of pens -- and finally even a metal nail.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: And the metal nail is famous for having a lot of bacteria on it and the gums are a bacterial highway to the heart, similar to as a drug abuser, putting bacteria into the veins. That's why we're seeing so many heart valve infections. We have 15,000 in the United States every year, so he went to see Mark, his primary care doctor in Cornwall, England, who saw that he had fevers and sweats and a heart murmur and sent him home. Now, here in the United States, I would do an echo -- and echocardiogram to examine the valves of the heart. I'm shocked that he was sent home, but it may in fact be an indictment of the National Health Service that that actually happened.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Well, we always like indicting the National Health Service just for Elizabeth Warren's sake, but just be clear on this. When President Garfield got shot, it is said that it wasn't the bullet that killed him, but everyone poking around inside and trying to find the bullet. And something similar happened here. It's not the popcorn, it's all the stuff he put in his mouth poking around to try and get at the popcorn, which is what everyone does.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: And that's the moral of the story. The gums guns are loaded with blood vessels with veins and if you make them bleed, and you get an abscess in those gums, you better see your dentist right away, because that abscess can feed the bloodstream, which then feeds the heart. You don't even have to have -- now what is the valve? It's the chambers of the heart opening and closing. They're very susceptible to bacteria in the bloodstream, so I would warn everybody out there not to poke around with foreign objects like we all do. This could happen to you, and then it ends up with a $50,000.00 hospitalization and surgery.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: But why even do you see in some restaurants toothpicks?

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: Well, toothpicks are okay provided that they're clean, provided that to use them for a specific device, but medically floss is much safer, brushing your teeth is much safer.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Okay, thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: I would say one more thing. I would advise everyone out there, watch Netflix or Hulu or Fox. Don't go to movie theaters because popcorn is rampant there.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Yeah, popcorn.

utterances.speaker: SIEGEL
utterances.utterance: Watch out for popcorn.

utterances.speaker: STEYN
utterances.utterance: Thank you Dr. Siegel. Popcorn. It's America's silent killer. It's coming for you. Dr. Siegel, thanks for that. That's about it for us tonight.
